Type.Name: Directory
Type.ThreadingSafetyStatement: All public static members of this type are safe for multithreaded operations. No instance members are guaranteed to be thread safe.

summary.para: Provides information and performs operations on directories.

remarks.para: Implementations are required to preserve the case of file and directory path strings, and to be case sensitive if and only if the current platform is case-sensitive.

para.block: In most methods that accept arguments, the path can refer to a file or a directory.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.IO.DirectoryInfo CreateDirectory (string path);

Docs.param: A containing the path to be created.
Docs.summary: Creates the specified path and any additional parents if non-existant.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.IO.DirectoryInfo CreateDirectory (string path, System.Security.AccessControl.DirectorySecurity directorySecurity);

Docs.param: A containing the name of the directory to delete. This directory must be writable and empty.

summary.para: Deletes the empty directory specified in .

remarks.para: This method behaves identically to (, ).

The argument is permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .

Docs.param: A containing the name of the directory to check.

summary.para: Returns a indicating whether the specified directory exists.

returns.para: if the caller has the required permissions and contains the name of an existing directory; otherwise, . If is , a zero-length string, or contains the name of a file, returns .

remarks.para: If the caller does not have sufficient permissions to read the files in the directory specified by , no exception is thrown and the method returns regardless of the existence of .

The argument is permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .

The names returned by this method are prefixed with the directory information provided in .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static class System.String[] GetDirectories(string path, string searchPattern)
public static string[] GetDirectories (string path, string searchPattern);

Docs.param: A containing the starting location for the search.
A containing the text pattern to match against the names of subdirectories of . cannot end with "..", or contain ".." followed by or .

summary.para: Returns the names of subdirectories in the specified directory that match the specified search pattern.

returns.para: A array containing the names of subdirectories of that match .

remarks.para: The following wild card specifiers are permitted in :

The period (".") character, if immediately followed by a wild card specifier, indicates that the period or the empty string matches the pattern. For example, "foo.*" and "foo.?" match "foo". Note that "foo.*" and "foo*" behave identically. If the period is not immediately followed by a wildcard, it has no special meaning (it represents a period).

Characters other than the wild card specifiers represent themselves, for example, the string "*t" searches for all names in ending with the letter "t". The string "s*" searches for all names in beginning with the letter "s".

The argument is permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .

Docs.exception: oris .
The caller does not have permission to access the requested information.

exception.para: is a zero-length string, contains only white space, or contains implementation-specific invalid characters.
does not contain a valid pattern.

Docs.exception: was not found.
The length of or the absolute path information for exceeds the system-defined maximum length.
is a file name.
Docs.permission: Requires permission to access path information for the specified directory and its subdirectories. See .
Docs.exception: The caller does not have permission to access the requested information.

MemberSignature.Value: public static string[] GetDirectories (string path, string searchPattern, System.IO.SearchOption searchOption);

public static string GetDirectoryRoot (string path);

Docs.param: A containing the name of a file or directory.

summary.para: Returns the path root component of the specified path.

returns.para: A containing the root information for the specified path.
Platforms that do not support this feature return .

remarks.para: This method obtains the full path information for , as returned by () and returns the path root component. The specified path is not required to exist.

The argument is permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .

exception.para: is a zero-length string, contains only white space, or contains one or more implementation-specific invalid characters.

Docs.exception: is .
The caller does not have the required permission.
The length of or the absolute path information for exceeds the system-defined maximum length.
Docs.permission: Requires permission to access path information for the specified file or directory. See

example.para: The following example demonstrates the method.

c.para: Path: pathtests.xyzzy Directory Root is C:\
Path: C:\ Directory Root is C:\

Docs.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static class System.String[] GetFiles(string path, string searchPattern)
public static string[] GetFiles (string path, string searchPattern);

Docs.param: A containing the name of the directory to search.
A containing the text pattern to match against the names of files in . cannot end with "..", or contain ".." followed by or .

summary.para: Returns the names of files in the specified directory that match the specified search pattern.

returns.para: A array containing the names of files in the specified directory that match the specified search pattern.

remarks.para: The following wild card specifiers are permitted in :

The period (".") character, if immediately followed by a wild card specifier, indicates that the period or the empty string matches the pattern. For example, "foo.*" and "foo.?" match "foo". Note that "foo.*" and "foo*" behave identically. If the period is not immediately followed by a wildcard, it has no special meaning (it represents a period).

Characters other than the wild card specifiers and the period always represent themselves, for example, the string "*t" searches for all names in ending with the letter "t". The string "s*" searches for all names in beginning with the letter "s".

The argument is permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .

Docs.exception: or is .

does not contain a valid pattern.

The caller does not have the required permission.
was not found.
The length of or the absolute path information for exceeds the system-defined maximum length.
Docs.permission: Requires permission to access path information for the specified directory and the files in that directory. See
Docs.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.

public static string[] GetFileSystemEntries (string path, string searchPattern);

Docs.param: A containing the name of the directory to search.
A containing the text pattern for which to search. cannot end with "..", or contain ".." followed by or .

summary.para: Returns an array of file and directory names matching the specified search criteria.

returns.para: A array containing file and directory names matching the specified search criteria.

remarks.para: The following wild card specifiers are permitted in :

The period (".") character, if immediately followed by a wild card specifier, indicates that the period or the empty string matches the pattern. For example, "foo.*" and "foo.?" match "foo". Note that "foo.*" and "foo*" behave identically. If the period is not immediately followed by a wildcard, it has no special meaning (it represents a period).

Characters other than the wild card specifiers represent themselves, for example, the string "*t" searches for all names in ending with the letter "t". The string "s*" searches for all names in beginning with the letter "s".

The names returned by this method are prefixed with the directory information provided in . The argument is permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .

.method public hidebysig static void Move(string sourceDirName, string destDirName)
public static void Move (string sourceDirName, string destDirName);

Docs.param: A containing the name of the file or directory to move.
A containing the new location for . This string cannot identify an existing file or directory.

summary.para: Moves a file or a directory and its contents to a new location.

remarks.para: The argument cannot specify a location on a different disk or volume than . The and arguments cannot identify the same file or directory.

para.block: This method throws a if, for example, you try to move "\mydir" to "\public", and "\public" already exists. You must specify "\public\mydir" as the .

remarks.para: The and arguments are permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .

Docs.exception: or is a zero-length string, contains only white space, or contains implementation-specific invalid characters.
or is .
The caller does not have the required permission.

exception.para: An attempt was made to move a directory to a different volume,
and refer to the same file or directory.

The length or absolute path information for or exceeds the system-defined maximum length.

summary.para: Sets the creation date and time for the specified file or directory.

remarks.para: The argument is permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .
On platforms that do not support this feature, this method has no effect. If this feature is supported, the range of dates that is valid for this operation is implementation-specific.

.method public hidebysig static void SetCurrentDirectory(string path)
public static void SetCurrentDirectory (string path);

Docs.param: A containing the path to which the current working directory is set.

summary.para: Sets the application's current working directory to the specified directory.

remarks.para: When the application terminates, the working directory is restored to its original location (the directory where the process was started).

The argument is permitted to specify relative or absolute path information. Relative path information is interpreted as relative to the current working directory. To obtain the current working directory, see .
On platforms that do not support this feature, this method has no effect.
